description: Model Building and Linear Programming: Graphical Methods and The Simplex Method, the LINDO and LINGO Computer Packages, Degeneracies, Minimization and the BigM and the Two-Phase Methods, and Goal Programming. Sensitivity Analysis: Geometric and Algebraic Approaches, The Computer and Sensitivity Analysis, The Dual of An LP Problem, The Dual Theorem, Shadow Prices, Complementary Slackness, The Dual Simplex Method, and The Revised Simplex Method. Integer Programming: The Branch and Bound Method, Enumeration Methods, and the Cutting Plane Method. Nonlinear Programming: Review of Differential Calculus, Convex and Concave Functions, Solving NLP Problems with One Variable, Uncontraint Nonlinear Optimization with Several Variables, Lagrange Multipliers and Constraint Nonlinear Optimization with Several Variables, The Kuhn-Tucker Conditions and Quadratic Programming.
name: OPTIMIZATION OF SYSTEMS

values.comments:
This class covers model building and linear programming: graphical methods and
the simplex method, the LINDO and LINGO computer packages, degeneracies,
minimization and the BigM and the two-phase methods, and goal programming.
Sensitivity analysis: geometric and algebraic approaches, the computer and sensitivity
analysis, the dual of an LP problem, the dual theorem, shadow prices, complementary
slackness, the dual simplex method, and the revised Simplex method. Integer
Programming: the branch and bound method, enumeration methods, and the cutting plane
method. Nonlinear programming: review of differential calculus, convex and concave
functions, solving NLP problems with one variable, unconstraint nonlinear optimization
with several variables, Lagrange multipliers and constraint nonlinear optimization with
several variables, the Kuhn-Tucker conditions and quadratic programming.
This course was thought to be an interesting course overall. Students thought that
"the course was useful … I learned a lot about how to formulate and solve problems."
One student surmised that the "course material is a bit dry, but straightforward and easy
to grasp when enough effort is put in."
Not much was said about the professor except that the notes he gave to the class
were re-written notes from the Handbook. His notes were more confusing than the
Handbook, which was very well-written and very good. Therefore, some students felt
that they did not need to attend class and get the notes, as long as you learned from the
Handbook. It was useful that the professor laid out everything for the course beforehand.
Homework sets and quizzes were given in this class. The homework was a good
depiction of the exam questions and the quizzes was not relevant to the material from the
homework set. The Handbook for the class is thought to be an excellent guide for this
course.
